Author of The Art of Body Acceptance
Weight inclusive workshops & online group programs
Art therapy acc: @makeartaboutit

node.text:
As most of you know, I adore sculpture because through the material of clay you can create any shape you want. The control is in your hands, and in a way, out of your hands. Clay is one of those materials that you need to get to know, to move through frustrations you have with it, enjoy the flow times and also be prepared to let it all go (especially if it explodes or something strange happens during firing it!). I've taken this process around a few cities in Australia, and in October it will come to the States as part of a larger workshop (see my site for details). The piece I timelapsed was around 40 minutes of work, and yes, I could refine it more but that's not the point. The process is what is most valuable for me, not what it ends up looking like. As I connect with the clay body, I can connect compassionately with my own.

#bodyimage #arttherapy #artheals

node.text: This is one of my favourite, yet simple art therapy directives - where you trace your hands, arms, and even your entire body (need lots of paper for that one!) and then you express what's going on inside your body with line, shape and colour, including perhaps what it feels like outside of the tracing. It's super interesting to see how the inside and the outside meet (or doesn't if there's quite a disconnect). Whatever comes through in the image is perfectly okay. The purpose is to explore with art materials, to translate the sensations and emotions you feel inside - or just play - to see what comes through when you let go of control and let your intuition guide you. I think making art images like this can be more representative of ourselves than the photos we take of our outsides. What would your image look like? If you could show people who you are in your body without just seeing your outsides?

node.text:
Most of us have had a bad experience with art, some more than others, and in ways that have lead to feelings of shame and avoidance of self expression. This video is for those who are coming or thinking about coming to my USA workshops where there is a creative art component, to help normalize fears about art making and start to orient with what art as therapeutic tool looks like.
*reuploaded because of a small sync issue on igtv, but it's still there so yolo*

node.text: The Body Reconnect Tour (BRT) brings to six US cities a workshop all about you and your body - how to compassionately reconnect with it by exploring positive body image, embodiment, creativity, self-acceptance and social connection. It will be fun, relaxing, informative and most of all - healing.  Learn more at www.bodyreconnecttour.com

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HaมN S TEAASN-AVA SPOTSLEFT FOR EUROPEI SPOTS AUSTRALIA + Round 31 Sept 1 4 starts Ang Creatively Embodied A 7 week online group program for nurturing a more peaceful relationship with your body. bodyimage-therapist.com/ce'.

node.text:
There are 4 spots left in the Australia and Europe Creatively Embodied group! We start on Sept 1th for Australia and Euro timezones. This group is currently the best way to work with me as I'm not taking on new 1 on 1 clients right now as I'm fully booked, and it's also the most cost effective way to access more personalised body image support.🌿🎨
.
.

Creatively Embodied is an online, weekly body image group using therapeutic art making and education to help build skills and insight to nurture a more peaceful relationship with yourself and your body. Over the span of seven sessions you will discover and learn in-depth ways of using the concept of a 'body narrative' to explore the themes, characters and dynamics of your story. This will help you re-experience your body in a less critical and more compassionate way. There is a session outline on my website for more details 🙂 During our time together, I will guide you through this process and support you to feel empowered to reclaim your body narrative from society and embody your right to re-define your story. If you've found 'cognitive' ways of working with body image not too effective (analysing forever but not feeling shifts in your experience), give this a go. It's also suitable if you've not tried other methods either.
.
.

As a side note, the art making part isn't there to make you feel bad about your skill level or 'lack of talent' it's used therapeutically to support you to work on perfectionism, develop interoceptive awareness and broaden self-expression -  key areas to work on when it comes to body image and embodiment. You don't need any art skills or talent to be in this group, you can be the worst at art and still benefit.
.
.

Each group has a maximum of 8-10 members and sessions are NOT recorded (slides and worksheets still sent if you miss a session). Payment plans available. Let me know your questions in the comments or send me an email 🙂
.
.

#bodyimage #healthateverysize #bodypositivity #artheals #arttherapy #weightstigma #mentalhealth #bodydysmorphia #edrecovery #intuitiveeating #dietculture #haes #nondiet #antidiet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HaมN S TEAASN-AVA SPOTSLEFT FOR EUROPEI SPOTS AUSTRALIA + Round 31 Sept 1 4 starts Ang Creatively Embodied A 7 week online group program for nurturing a more peaceful relationship with your body. bodyimage-therapist.com/ce'.

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Overview Creatively Embodied 1S a session, weekly online body image group program. We use education, therapeutic art making and the 'body narrative concept to help build skills and insight to nurture a more peaceful relationship with yourself and your body. No art skills or 'talent' needed. (you can be terrible at art) Must be 18 or older unwell and currently not acutely bodyimage-therapist.com/ce'.

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Who is 1t for? This online group program provides a warm, nurturing environment for anyone who experiences a high level of body criticism and finds it difficult to access self-compassion or soothe emotions. If you're ready to learn and work on what keeps you stuck in this dynamic this group is for you. Must be 18 or older unwell and currently not acutely bodyimage-therapist.com/ce'.

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Details Three groups will run every week for 7 weeks starting from: USA/ Canada Eastern: ET, USA September Aust/Europe: Aust/ Wednesdays, 6.30 8pm AEST, 1st September You may jờin from anywhere as long you can make these times work for you! bodyimage-therapist.com/ce'.

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Cost $410 AUD (Approx $315 USD) To secure your place: Booking requires a $90 AUD non-refundable deposit with the balance or first instalment due at least 7 days before the start date Payment plans avail. See website for more details and to book. bodyimage-therapist.com/c com/ ce'.

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Seeing your body as 'beautiful' 1S not a prerequisite for positive body image. The Body Image Therapist Ashlee Bennett'.

node.text:
Positive body image isn't forcing yourself to see your body as beautiful and then feeling worthy because of its beauty. While some of you may sense the beauty of your body, it's not a prerequisite for positive body image. Body image researchers see positive body image as multidimensional. Positive body image is about connecting with a sense of appreciation for how your body supports you as best as it can, accepting your body as it is, being flexible and open to how it naturally changes over time, recognising that your body contributes to diversity, and cultivating a sense of worth from the inside out. Instead of trying to see yourself as 'beautiful' take that criterion off the table and explore some of the above points instead. Beauty isn't everything, even though our culture tells us it is - oh and that's another part of positive body image, the practise of rejecting beauty ideals and narrow concepts of beauty!
.
.

#bodyimage #healthateverysize #haes #mentalhealth #nondiet #edrecovery #arttherapy #intuitiveeating #psychology #therapy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 16, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person and text that says 'Body Image Tip Take a life drawing class.'.

node.text:
Something I am really grateful for after having attended art school is the amount of life drawing I did. It was the first time I got to see all kinds of bodies up close and in the flesh - old, young, big, small, disabled, non-disabled. It was a setting where I got to really take in the wonder in all living breathing physical forms for hours at at a time. It set me up to see life and our bodies through an art lens, which for me is a lens of appreciation. It helped me observe bodies just as they are, and by extension, view my own body just as it is. And when I say 'art lens' it doesn't mean 'seeing the beauty in everything' - finding something beautiful in art isn't the point of art. For me, art is more broadly about capturing or expressing a sense or state of existence and is a commentary/documentation of life.
.
.

If you feel called, look up some local life drawing classes - even if you can't draw. The therapeutic aspect of life drawing goes beyond how well you can draw what you see. There are many ways to explore body image work, some are deep and direct and some are less obvious yet still helpful 🙂 one of my dreams is to eventually run a therapeutic life drawing class for body image work (but it needs to get in line with all my other ideas haha). Have you done life drawing?
.
.

#bodyimage #healthateverysize #haes #lifedrawing #arttherapy #artheals #psychology #artjournalling #mentalhealth #edrecovery #therapy #nondiet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 10, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Let your relationship with your body evolve and reveal itself over time. It's unrealistic for it to swing from all bad to all good. Your relationship with your body is like any other relationship takes time to develop safety, earn trust, build intimacy and accept that the relationship is perfectly imperfect. The Body Image Û Therapist Ashlee'.

node.text:
I know how frantic it can feel to just want to feel okay, accept and even love your body. Especially when dieting your way out of a negative body image isn't a helpful option - you may feel a massive urge to now need to accept your body to feel okay, to swing to the other side as fast as possible. When in reality, there's nothing super simple about being in relationship with your body if for the longest time it's been a battle ground. 
.
.

Let's try on another perspective for a moment - what if we pause, without judgement, in the recognition that your relationship with your body is complicated, messy and you don't know what to do? This is a valid place to be. Be in this space for a while, in the unknown. Sit in not having the answer,  just for now. Be with your emotions and give space for the way forward to emerge organically, from the wisdom of your body, instead of rushing to problem solve with the mind.
.
.

Take time with your body relationship - there's little value in bypassing all the bits in the middle and just to get to the juicy end part - that's what diet culture has conditioned a lot of us to do, so don't be hard on yourself as you navigate and sit in all the mess.
.
.

#bodyimage #healthateverysize #haes #haesig #bodypositivity #dietculture #therapy #mentalhealth #bodyacceptance #intuitiveeating
#edrecovery #arttherapy #psychology #therapy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 03, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Ashlee Bennett, AThR Creator f The CrTh Body Image Therapist M THE Art OF BODY ACCEPTANCE Strengthen Your Relationship with Yourself Through Therapeutic Creative Exercises'.

node.text:
It's been 3 months since The Art of Body Acceptance was published and launched out into the world. Time flies! This book is a very practical, arts based exploration of your relationship with yourself and your body. It's definitely not something to read and do all in one sitting. It's a guide and a resource to revisit over time. If you're worried you're not creative enough, the 1st chapter is completely dedicated to reclaiming creativity, even for non creatives who believe they never had it to begin with. At the end of the day, art is a language and it's another way we can express ourselves, take up space and develop insight and meaning in our lives. 
.
.

It's available anywhere you get your books! 
.
.

#bodyimage #psychology #healthateverysize #haesig #therapy #counselling #creativity #mentalhealth #edrecovery #intuitiveeating #nondiet #artheals #arttherapy #artjournalling

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on August 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Praising weight loss 1S still a judgement. The Body Image Therapist Ashlee Bennett'.

node.text:
Usually, the word 'judgement' brings to mind something negative. However, judgements are judgements. Judgements can be considered as acceptable all the way to taboo. For example, it's more acceptable to say 'oh wow you've lost weight, good job!' and more taboo to say 'you've gained weight, what happened?'. Just because one is more socially acceptable, doesn't mean the praised-based 'positive judgement' is helpful or positive for the person. Whether it be praising or scolding, judgements create a hierarchical interaction. It is implied that the person doing the judging has more ability than the person being judged. If a person thrives off praise, praise will always be based on the values system of the person dishing it out.
.
.

If you've noticed someone's weight change - it is not your task to pass judgement on that - positive or negative. If you thrive off people commenting positively on your body, especially after weight or body related change, what are you really seeking from them? Get curious. 
.
.

I understand this is a topic of debate. This is the angle I take. If this doesn't vibe with you, that's okay. May it be food for thought.
.
.

In other news, did you get to see my last few posts? When I mention specific words Instagram reduces the reach of those posts! If you like my content and don't want to miss a post, turn on notifications 🙂
.
.

#psychology #arttherapy #healthateverysize #edrecovery #mentalhealth  #wellbeing #weightstigma #dietculture #selflove #gratitude #bodypositivity #haes #bodyimage #counselling #therapy #mindfulness

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on July 31, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'When a new way of relating to yourself and your body seems so inconceivable, just gently plant the seed of its possibility, nothing more. The Body Image Therapist| Ashlee Bennett'.

node.text:
When we've spent a long time relating to ourselves and our bodies in a particular way, it can be challenging to make even a bit of space for the possibility that this experience could be different. Years and decades of reinforced belief patterns and unresolved trauma can make it almost seem impossible to even fathom a way out of the darkness.
.
.

There are parts of you that have felt so hurt, unseen and unheard, they have retreated into a space internally that is like a room without any windows or light. They feel a relative sense of security and familiarity in there even though they're in pain. From their perspective, trying to feel positive or even imagine a world outside of that dark space may seem out of reach. And you know what, right now that’s okay. Witness the sense of stuckness they have with compassion and non-judgement, and when they’re ready with their consent, invite them to imagine what it may be like to hold just the *possibility* that they have what it takes inside of them to venture out of that room, even if they have no idea how yet. Let the possibility of it be enough right now and sit in that sense for a while without looking for solutions.
.
.

#bodyimage #dietculture #healthateverysize #haes #intuitiveeating #nondiet #mentalhealth #psychology #dietculture #bodydysmorphia #edrecovery #arttherapy #artheals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on July 30, 2021. May be an illustration of text that says 'MUIN Kad 23 Round 31 Sept 1 4 starts Aug Creatively Embodied A 7 week online group program for nurturing a more peaceful relationship with your body. bodyimage-therapist.com/ce'.

node.text:
ROUND 4 of Creatively Embodied is here! The last round completely filled up within 2 weeks so reserve your spot as soon as you can. We start August 31st or Sept 1th or 5th depending on where you are in the world. This group is currently the best way to work with me as I'm not taking on new 1 on 1 clients right now as I'm fully booked, and it's also the most cost effective way to access more personalised body image support.🌿🎨
.
.

Creatively Embodied is an online, weekly body image group using therapeutic art making and narrative/storytelling to help build skills and insight to nurture a more peaceful relationship with yourself and your body. Over the span of seven sessions you will discover and learn in-depth ways of using the concept of a 'body narrative' to explore the themes, characters and dynamics of your story. This will help you re-experience your body in a less critical and more compassionate way. There is a session outline on my website for more details 🙂 During our time together, I will guide you through this process and support you to feel empowered to reclaim your body narrative from society and embody your right to re-define your story. If you've found 'cognitive' ways of working with body image not too effective (analysing forever but not feeling shifts in your experience), give this a go. It's also suitable if you've not tried other methods either.
.
.

As a side note, the art making part isn't there to make you feel bad about your skill level or 'lack of talent' it's used therapeutically to support you to work on perfectionism, develop interoceptive awareness and broaden self-expression -  key areas to work on when it comes to body image and embodiment. You don't need any art skills or talent to be in this group, you can be the worst at art and still benefit.
.
.

Each group has a maximum of 10 members and sessions are NOT recorded. Payment plans available. Let me know your questions in the comments or send me an email 🙂
.
.

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on July 25, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The intention to only make "good art squashes creativity 中年新透æ肌集电能合 and self expression. ~Make Art About It~ -Ashlee Bennett-'.

node.text:
@makeartaboutit is my other account all about art therapy, creativity and self-expression. If that's something which interests you or you're curious, head over there and have a bit of a read and follow along. Something else I'm really passionate about is making art and creativity more accessible as a form of self expression and using creative methods therapeutically. 
.
.

When I was writing The Art of Body Acceptance, I wrote a chapter on reclaiming creativity and I felt it flow through me with such ease, and I know I have a lot more to say on the topic. I hope to see some of you over there 🎉🎨🌱
.
.

#arttherapy #artheals #artjournalling #creativity #therapy #selfacceptance #traumahealing #selfcare #artofbodyacceptance

Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on July 24, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Aim for body neutrality rather than body love. Let body love flow in and out instead of needing it to be a baseline. The Body Image Therapist Ashlee Bennett'.

node.text:
While there's nothing wrong with body love, body neutrality can be a more realistic concept to hold the complexity of experiences in your body. Body love (or body positivity as some call it), can conjure up black and white ideas that you'll 'always' feel good in your body, love the way it looks and be in the mood to celebrate your appearance all the time. Not experiencing these things all the time doesnt mean you've still got work to do - nope! Just like goals around happiness 100% of the time, our experiences in our bodies are varied, layered, paradoxical, multicoloured - trying to hold a single view or feeling about your body is an exhausting job and a bit of a cruel task.
.
.

Body neutrality is a gentle baseline - it's that place where things are neither terrible or wonderful - your body 'just is', and from that baseline a wide variety of experiences which are temporary and moving flow through. Some experiences go above the baseline, some below. Over time, you will develop your own definition of body love. Some who sit in that deeper definition typically see body love as deep respect, appreciation and unconditional acceptance of the existence of their body and who they are inside - even when experiences are hard. It's unconditional and not dependant on 'loving, liking' feelings, it's a fierce position of being on your own side even in a storm, not abandoning your existence when it gets hard.
.
.

#bodyimage #dietculture #therapy #healthateverysize #bodypositivity #bodylove #bodyneutrality #nondiet #compassion #mentalhealth #edrecovery #intuitiveeating #haes

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on July 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Emotional eating is not weak or shameful. It's often a resourceful coping tool in response to an environment where there was, or is, little access to other resources to support emotional regulation. The Body Image Therapist Ashlee Bennett'.

node.text:
There can be so many feelings of shame around particular ways of coping with emotions and a dysregulated nervous system. When it comes to food, thoughts like 'it's weak', 'I should be smarter than this', 'it's embarrassing that I rely on it to cope' can be present and often increase distress. It's interesting to reflect how the judgements we have about food being used as a coping tool relate to fat stereotypes - gluttonous, unintelligent, weak-willed even immature.
.
.

Sometimes the work initially around exploring emotional eating is diffusing some of the judgement you have about doing it (again emotional eating can also be a normal part of a peaceful relationship with food). We can recognise that diet culture has demonised the emotional part of eating - enjoying food, finding it pleasurable is a valid, normal part of eating. If we get curious for a bit, if the fear of weight gain people feel around emotional eating wasn't present, how would our relationship to the emotionality of food shift? Would it be as stigmatised? 
.
.

Let's have compassion and really notice the parts of us, usually the young parts of ourselves, resilience in finding a way to soothe and comfort in less than ideal environments. They really need to be recognised as doing a wonderful job to gather the resources they had access to at the time, when food was really one of the only options to help contain some big feelings and experiences. Yes, there may be some other ways to deal in the now, but it's not about that right now, give them the acknowledgement they deserve and need.
.
.

#bodyimage #healthateverysize #haes  #intuitiveeating #dietculture #therapy #edrecovery #arttherapy #bodypositivity  #emotionaleating #bingeating #psychology #bodydysmorphia #mentalhealth

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ashlee Bennett, AThR on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Body Image Tip Before you immediately delete a photo you dislike, sit with it for a moment, purposefully relax your muscles, slow your breathing, and ask if there is a part of you willing to bring a gentle, loving gaze to the whole, complex person you see there in the image. Take the image in with a sense of wonder and curiosity, as if you've never seen a picture of a human before. The Body Image Therapist Ashlee Bennett'.

node.text:
The first instinct is often *delete picture immediately* to avoid uncomfortable feelings that come with automatic critical thoughts. These automatic thoughts come from your brain when it's on autopilot - when you delay the quick delete, you have a chance to bring your brain online so you can practise a new experience by welcoming fresh eyes and less critical lens to the image. Pause, ground yourself and try to see 'what is' without giving it meaning, instead of making the same automatic evaluation. 
.
.

Ask a nurturing part of you if they would be willing to support you to see yourself in the image as a whole human, even when the body critic worries about what double chins, rolls, awkward expressions, blemished skin means about you as a person. Can you make space to take in the wonder you naturally are? All of the systems, cells, biological co-oridination that keeps you alive as best they can? Seeing yourself this way doesn't need to be all of your experience, but can it be a part of it, even if it creates a paradox? Can you make an inner space where you can rest sometimes in the knowledge there's nothing you need to change about your appearance to be complete?
.
.

#bodyimage #healthateverysize #bodypositivity #trauma #feminism #bodydysmorphia #edrecovery #arttherapy #compassion #mentalhealth #haes #psychology #therapy #intuitiveeating #dietitian #dietculture
